Series: Multiple Indicator Cluster Survey (MICS), MICS Program Surveys
Summary: The Suriname MICS 2018 was conducted as part of Round 6 of this survey series. Areas covered include nutrition, child health, water and sanitation, reproductive health, child development, education, child protection, sexual behavior, and access to mass media.

Series: Sierra Leone Integrated Household Survey (SLIHS), Living Standards Measurement Study (LSMS), Living Standards Measurement Study (LSMS) - World Bank
Summary: ""The Sierra Leone Integrated Household Survey (SLIHS) is Sierra Leone’s Living Standard Measurement Survey (LSMS) or household income and expenditure survey (HIES), which is conducted regularly in order to collect useful socio-economic data to support government planning processes. The 2018 SLIHS data collection covered the period January-December 2018, and it was the third round, which followed the 2011 and 2003 rounds. SLIHS is a multi-topic household survey that collects detailed household incomes and expenditures, which are the ingredient for the monetary poverty assessment and collects information on education, health, employment, housing, and household assets.""
Suggested citation: Government of Sierra Leone, Statistics Sierra Leone, World Bank. Sierra Leone Integrated Household Survey 2018.

Series: Multiple Indicator Cluster Survey (MICS), MICS Program Surveys
Summary: The Zimbabwe Multiple Cluster Indicator Survey (MICS) 2019 is part of MICS6, an international survey initiative to monitor the situation of children and women. Topics commonly covered in MICS include immunization, education, child and maternal health, family planning, and HIV/AIDS. MICS also provides data for tracking progress toward Millennium Development Goals (MDGs), particularly those related to health, education, and mortality. Interviews were successfully completed for 10,129 women ages 15-49 and 4,178 men ages 15-54 from 11,091 households. Additionally, 6,102 questionnaires were completed for children under 5.
Suggested citation: United Nations Children's Fund (UNICEF), Zimbabwe National Statistics Agency. Zimbabwe Multiple Indicator Cluster Survey 2019. New York, United States of America: United Nations Children's Fund (UNICEF), 2020.

Series: Multiple Indicator Cluster Survey (MICS), MICS Program Surveys
Summary: The Bangladesh Multiple Cluster Indicator Survey (MICS) 2019 is part of MICS6, an international survey initiative to monitor the situation of children and women. Topics commonly covered in MICS include immunization, education, child and maternal health, family planning, and HIV/AIDS. MICS also provides data for tracking progress toward Millennium Development Goals (MDGS), particularly those related to health, education and mortality. For the 2019 Bangladesh MICS, 61,242 households were successfully interviewed, and questionnaires for the following were completed: 64,378 women age 15-49, 40,617 children age 5-17, and 23,099 children under 5. Additionally, 12,238 households and 3,028 water sources underwent water quality testing for arsenic, and 6,069 households were tested for E. coli.
Suggested citation: Bangladesh Bureau of Statistics (BBS), Government of Bangladesh, United Nations Children's Fund (UNICEF). Bangladesh Multiple Indicator Cluster Survey 2019.

Series: Multiple Indicator Cluster Survey (MICS), MICS Program Surveys
Summary: The Kiribati Multiple Indicator Cluster Survey 2018-2019 is part of MICS6, an international survey initiative to monitor the situation of children and women. The survey covers health, education, child protection, immunization, contraceptive use, and symptoms such as diarrhea, cough, and fever.
Suggested citation: Kiribati National Statistics Office, Ministry of Health and Medical Services (Kiribati), Secretariat of the Pacific Community (SPC), United Nations Children's Fund (UNICEF), United Nations Population Fund (UNFPA). Kiribati Multiple Indicator Cluster Survey 2018-2019. New York, United States of America: United Nations Children's Fund (UNICEF), 2020.

Series: Turkey Demographic and Health Survey , DHS Standard Demographic and Health Survey (DHS), DHS Program Surveys
Summary: The purpose of this survey was to gather data at the household level in order to formulate national indicators related to demographics, fertility, child mortality, maternal health, and nutritional status of women and children. The data were collected through in-person interviews in the home. The survey included questionnaires for the household and for individuals. Women aged 15 through 49 years were asked a specific set of questions on fertility related topics. Measurements of height and weight were taken from mothers and children. The survey was based on the international Macro DHS model questionnaires and those used in previous Turkish health surveys.
Suggested citation: Institute of Population Studies, Hacettepe University, Ministry of Development (Turkey), Ministry of Health (Turkey). Turkey Demographic and Health Survey 2018-2019.

GHDx Record Title: Pakistan Social and Living Standards Measurement Survey/ Household Integrated Economic Survey 2018-2019
Series: Pakistan Social and Living Standard Measurement Survey (PSLM), Pakistan Household Integrated Economic Survey (HIES)
Summary:
The Pakistan Social and Living Standards Measurement Surveys (PSLM) are designed to collect data on social issues, behavioral practices, and health status. The PSLM is designed to be compared with past rounds of the PSLM for trend analysis, and to provide data for monitoring progress toward Pakistan's Millennium Development Goals (MDGs), and Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs).
For the 2018-2019 PSLM/HIES, data were collected from 24,809 households in the four provinces of Pakistan.
Suggested citation: Government of Pakistan, Ministry of Planning and Development (Pakistan), Pakistan Bureau of Statistics. Pakistan Social and Living Standards Measurement Survey/ Household Integrated Economic Survey 2018-2019. Islamabad, Pakistan: Pakistan Bureau of Statistics, 2020.

Series: DHS Standard Demographic and Health Survey (DHS), DHS Program Surveys
Summary: The 2017-18 Bangladesh Demographic and Health Survey (BDHS), is part of Phase 7 of the DHS series; a comprehensive, nationally representative household survey series. 20,127 ever-married women ages 15-49 were interviewed from a sample size of 19,457 households. The 2017-18 BDHS used six types of questionnaires: (1) the Household Questionnaire, (2) the Woman’s Questionnaire (completed by ever-married women age 15-49), (3) the Biomarker Questionnaire, (4) two verbal autopsy questionnaires to collect data on causes of death among children under age 5, (5) the Community Questionnaire, and (6) the Fieldworker Questionnaire.
Suggested citation: ICF International, Mitra and Associates, National Institute of Population Research and Training (NIPORT). Bangladesh Demographic and Health Survey 2017-2018. Fairfax, United States of America: ICF International, 2020.

GHDx Record Title: Senegal Continuous Demographic and Health Survey 2018
Series: DHS Standard Demographic and Health Survey (DHS), DHS Program Surveys
Summary: The Senegal Continuous Demographic and Health Survey (DHS) 2018 is part of phase 8 of the Demographic and Health Survey (DHS) series, a nationally representative household survey series. Topics commonly covered in DHS include child and maternal health, family planning, nutrition, health behavior and knowledge, health care access and use, and immunization. For the 2018 Senegal Continuous DHS, 9,414 ever married women ages 15-49 and 3,764 men ages 15-59 were successfully interviewed from 4,592 households.
Suggested citation: Directorate of Forecasting and Statistics, Ministry of the Economy, Finance and Planning (Senegal), ICF International, Ministry of Health and Social Action (Senegal), United States Agency for International Development (USAID). Senegal Continuous Demographic and Health Survey 2018. Fairfax, United States of America: ICF International, 2020.

Data provider: National Institute of Statistics and Informatics (Peru)
Series: Peru Demographic and Family Health Survey (ENDES)
Suggested citation: National Institute of Statistics and Informatics (Peru). Peru Demographic and Family Health Survey 2019. Lima, Peru: National Institute of Statistics and Informatics (Peru).

GHDx Record Title: Costa Rica Multiple Indicator Cluster Survey 2018
Series: Multiple Indicator Cluster Survey (MICS), MICS Program Surveys
Summary: The sample for the National Survey of Women, Childhood and Adolescence (EMNA) was used to provide estimates for a large number of indicators on the conditions of women, children and adolescence at the national level, by urban and rural area, as well as the seven provinces of the country: San José, Alajuela, Cartago, Heredia, Guanacaste, Puntarenas and Limón. Four questionnaires were used in the survey: 1) a household questionnaire to collect basic demographic information about all the people who are de jure household members; 2) a questionnaire for individual women applied in each home to all women 15-49 years of age; 3) a questionnaire for children under 5 years old, administered to mothers (or caregivers) of all minor children 5 years living in the home; and 4) a questionnaire for children from 5 to 17 years of age, answered by the mother (or caregiver).
Suggested citation: Ministry of Health (Costa Rica), National Institute of Statistics and Censuses (Costa Rica), United Nations Children's Fund (UNICEF). Costa Rica Multiple Indicator Cluster Survey 2018. New York, United States of America: United Nations Children's Fund (UNICEF), 2020.

GHDx Record Title: North Macedonia Multiple Indicator Cluster Survey 2018-2019
Series: Multiple Indicator Cluster Survey (MICS), MICS Program Surveys
Summary:
In 2018-2019, two Multiple Indicator Cluster Surveys were carried out in North Macedonia using two different samples: one was the 2018-2019 North Macedonia MICS and the other was the 2018-2019 North Macedonia Roma Settlements MICS. The 2018-2019 North Macedonia MICS was carried out based on a national sample representative of the whole population of North Macedonia. The 2018-2019 North Macedonia Roma Settlements MICS was carried out based on a Roma settlements sample representative of the population living in Roma settlements in the country. 
Four questionnaires were used in the surveys: 1) a household questionnaire; 2) a questionnaire for individual women administered in each household to all women age 15-49 years; 3) an under-5 questionnaire, administered to mothers (or caretakers); and 4) a questionnaire for children age 5-17 years, administered to the mother (or caretaker) of one randomly selected child age 5-17 years living in the household.
Suggested citation: Ipsos Strategic Puls, State Statistical Office (Republic of North Macedonia), United Nations Children's Fund (UNICEF). North Macedonia Multiple Indicator Cluster Survey 2018-2019. New York, United States of America: United Nations Children's Fund (UNICEF), 2020.

Series: Multiple Indicator Cluster Survey (MICS), MICS Program Surveys
Summary:
The sample for the Tonga MICS 2019 was designed to provide estimates for a large number of indicators on the situation of children and women at the national level, for urban and rural areas, and for divisions: Tongatapu, Vava’u, Ha’apai, ‘Eua and Ongo Niua. The urban and rural areas were identified as the main sampling strata and the sample of households was selected in two stages. Within each stratum, a specified number of census enumeration areas were selected systematically with probability proportional to size. After a household listing was carried out within the selected enumeration areas, a systematic sample of 20 households was drawn.
All of the selected enumeration areas were visited during the fieldwork data collection. The sampling frame was based on the 2016 Tonga Census of Population and Housing. It was calculated that 139 sample clusters would need to be selected in total.
Suggested citation: Government of Tonga, Pacific Community Statistics for Development Division, Tonga Department of Statistics, United Nations Children's Fund (UNICEF), United Nations Population Fund (UNFPA). Tonga Multiple Indicator Cluster Survey 2019. New York, United States of America: United Nations Children's Fund (UNICEF), 2020.

Series: Multiple Indicator Cluster Survey (MICS), MICS Program Surveys
Summary:
The sample for the 2019 Turkmenistan MICS was designed to provide estimates for a large number of indicators on the situation of children and women at the national level, for urban and rural areas, and for 6 regions: Ashgabat city, Akhal, Balkan, Dashoguz, Lebap and Mary velayats. The urban and rural areas within each region were identified as the main sampling strata and the sample of households was selected in two stages.
Four questionnaires were used in the survey: 1) a household questionnaire to collect basic demographic information on all de jure household members, the household, and the dwelling; 2) a questionnaire for individual women administered in each household to all women age 15-49 years; 3) an under-5 questionnaire, administered to mothers (or caretakers); and 4) a questionnaire for children age 5-17 years, administered to the mother (or caretaker) of one randomly selected child age 5-17 years living in the household.
Suggested citation: The State Committee of Turkmenistan for Statistics and UNICEF. 2020. 2019 Turkmenistan Multiple Indicator Cluster Survey. Survey Findings Report. Ashgabat, Turkmenistan: State Committee for Statistics of Turkmenistan and UNICEF.

Series: Multiple Indicator Cluster Survey (MICS), MICS Program Surveys, Samoa Demographic and Health Survey
Summary: The sample for the Samoa DHS-MICS 2019-20 was designed to provide estimates for indicators on the situation of children and women at the national level, for urban and rural areas, and for the four regions of the country: Apia Urban Area, North West Upolu, Rest of Upolu and Savaii. The urban and rural areas were identified as the main sampling strata and the sample of households was selected in two stages. Within each stratum, a specified number of census enumeration areas were selected using systematic equal probability sampling procedure. A systematic sample of 20 households from rural EAs and 15 households from urban EAs was drawn. All of the selected enumeration areas were visited during the fieldwork data collection. The sampling frame was based on 2016 Samoa Census of Population and Housing. It was calculated that 204 sample clusters would need to be selected in total. As the sample is not self-weighting, sample weights are used for reporting survey results.
Suggested citation: Pacific Community Statistics for Development Division, Samoa Bureau of Statistics, United Nations Children's Fund (UNICEF). Samoa Multiple Indicator Cluster Survey 2019-2020. New York, United States of America: United Nations Children's Fund (UNICEF), 2022.

Series: Multiple Indicator Cluster Survey (MICS), MICS Program Surveys
Summary:
The Guinea-Bissau Multiple Cluster Indicator Survey 2018-2019 is part of MICS6, an international survey initiative to monitor the situation of children and women. Interviews include: 7,379 households; 10,945 women ages 15-49 years; 7,484 mothers/caregivers of children under five; 5,836 mothers/caregivers of children ages 5-17; and 2,805 men. Households were also tested for water quality (1,828).
MICS used a two-stage stratified sampling method. The sampling base was based on the 2009 General Population and Housing Census (RGPH). Primary sampling units selected in the first stage were the enumeration zones (Districts of the Census) of the Census. A list of households has been drawn up in each Primary Unit of the sample and a sample of Households was selected in the second stage (Secondary Units).
Suggested citation: National Statistics Institute (Guinea-Bissau), United Nations Children's Fund (UNICEF). Guinea-Bissau Multiple Indicator Cluster Survey 2018-2019. New York, United States of America: United Nations Children's Fund (UNICEF), 2020.

Series: Multiple Indicator Cluster Survey (MICS), MICS Program Surveys
Summary: The MICS surveys were carried out in 2019 on two separate samples — the Serbia MICS on a nationally representative sample and the Serbia Roma Settlements MICS on a sample of Roma households living in Roma settlements. At the national level a total of 8,101 households were selected: 2,425 households with children and 5,676 households without children. The 2019 Serbia MICS sample is not self-weighting. In addition to the administration of questionnaires, fieldwork teams measured the weights and heights of children age under five years.
Suggested citation: Statistical Office of the Republic of Serbia and UNICEF. 2019. Serbia Multiple Indicator Cluster Survey and Serbia Roma Settlements Multiple Indicator Cluster Survey, 2019, Survey Findings Report. Belgrade, Serbia: Statistical Office of the Republic of Serbia and UNICEF.

Series: DHS Standard Demographic and Health Survey (DHS), DHS Program Surveys
Summary: The Liberia Demographic and Health Survey (DHS) 2019-2020 was conducted as part of phase 7 of the Demographic and Health Survey series. Topics commonly covered in the DHS include child and maternal health, family planning, nutrition, health behavior and knowledge, health care access and use, and immunization. In addition to a complete birth history for each respondent, this survey also collected a complete birth history for the mother of the respondent. For the 2019-2020 Liberia DHS, 3,338 women ages 15-49 and 1,563 men ages 15-59 were successfully interviewed from 3,321 households.
Suggested citation: ICF International, Liberia Institute for Statistics and Geo-information Services (LISGIS), Ministry of Health and Social Welfare (Liberia). Liberia Demographic and Health Survey 2019-2020. 2021.

Series: DHS Standard Demographic and Health Survey (DHS), DHS Program Surveys
Summary: The Gambia Demographic and Health Survey (DHS) 2019-2020 is part of Round 7 of the DHS series.
Suggested citation: Gambia Bureau of Statistics (GBOS), ICF International, Ministry of Health and Social Welfare (The Gambia). Gambia Demographic and Health Survey 2019-2020. Fairfax, United States of America: ICF International, 2021.

GHDx Record Title: Pakistan Special Demographic and Health Survey 2019
Series: DHS Special Demographic and Health Survey (Special DHS), DHS Program Surveys
Geography: Pakistan, Azad Jammu and Kashmir, Balochistan, Federally Administered Tribal Areas [Historical], Gilgit-Baltistan, Islamabad, Khyber Pakhtunkhwa, Punjab, Sindh
Summary: The 2019 Pakistan Maternal Mortality Survey (PMMS) sampling consisted of urban and rural areas of the four provinces of Pakistan (Punjab, Sindh, Khyber Pakhtunkhwa, and Balochistan), Azad Jammu and Kashmir (AJK), Gilgit Baltistan (GB), Federally Administered Tribal Areas (FATA), and the Islamabad Capital Territory (ICT). A total of 153,560 households (81,400 rural and 72,160 urban) were selected using a two-stage and two-phase stratified systematic sampling approach.Households that reported at least one death of a woman of reproductive age were then visited, and detailed verbal autopsies were conducted to determine the causes and circumstances of these deaths to help identify maternal deaths. Six questionnaires were used in the 2019 PMMS: the Short Household Questionnaire, the Long Household Questionnaire, the Woman’s Questionnaire, the Verbal Autopsy Questionnaire, the Community Questionnaire, and the Fieldworker Questionnaire.
Suggested citation: ICF International, National Institute of Population Studies (Pakistan). Pakistan Special Demographic and Health Survey 2019. Fairfax, United States of America: ICF International, 2020.

GHDx Record Title: Senegal Continuous Demographic and Health Survey 2019
Series: DHS Program Surveys, DHS Standard Demographic and Health Survey (DHS)
Summary: The Senegal Continuous Demographic and Health Survey (DHS) 2019 is part of phase 8 of the Demographic and Health Survey (DHS) series, a nationally representative household survey series. Topics commonly covered in DHS include child and maternal health, family planning, nutrition, health behavior and knowledge, health care access and use, and immunization. For the 2019 Senegal Continuous DHS, 8,649 ever married women ages 15-49 and 3,365 men ages 15-59 were successfully interviewed from 4,538 households.
Suggested citation: ICF International, Ministry of Health and Social Action (Senegal), National Agency of Statistics and Demography (Senegal), United States Agency for International Development (USAID). Senegal Continuous Demographic and Health Survey 2019. Fairfax, United States of America: ICF International, 2020.

Series: Multiple Indicator Cluster Survey (MICS), MICS Program Surveys
Summary: In 2019-2020, two MICS surveys were carried out in Kosovo using two different samples: one was the 2019-2020 Kosovo MICS and the other, the 2019-2020 Roma, Ashkali and Egyptian Communities in Kosovo MICS.  The two samples and their technical characteristics are described separately in the relevant sections of the report. Elements of the methodology and of findings that are common (snapshots, final report) for both surveys are presented jointly. In the Kosovo MICS, researchers interviewed 5,124 households. In the Roma, Ashkali and Egyptian Communities, researchers were able to interview 1,221 households.
Suggested citation: Kosovo Agency of Statistics, United Nations Children's Fund (UNICEF). Kosovo Multiple Indicator Cluster Survey 2019-2020. Fairfax, United States of America: ICF International, 2020.

Series: DHS Program Surveys, DHS Standard Demographic and Health Survey (DHS)
Summary:
The primary objective of the 2019-20 Rwanda DHS is to provide up-to-date estimates of basic demographic and health indicators. The survey collected information on fertility, awareness and use of family planning methods, breastfeeding practices, nutritional status of women and children, maternal and child health, adult and childhood mortality, women’s empowerment, domestic violence, awareness and behavior regarding HIV/AIDS and other sexually transmitted infections (STIs), and other health-related issues such as smoking. It also tested for the prevalence of anemia, malaria, HIV, and selected micronutrient indicators.
Data collection took place from November 9, 2019, to July 20, 2020. The data collection was interrupted for more than 2 months from March 21 to June 7, 2020, due the nationwide lockdown for the Coronavirus disease (COVID-19) pandemic.
Suggested citation: Ministry of Health (Rwanda), National Institute of Statistics (Rwanda), Rwanda Biomedical Center (RBC). Rwanda Demographic and Health Survey 2019-2020. Fairfax, United States of America: ICF International, 2021.

Series: Multiple Indicator Cluster Survey (MICS), MICS Program Surveys
Summary: The sample for the Nepal MICS 2019 samples were collected at urban and rural areas of seven provinces: Province 1, Province 2, Bagmati province, Gandaki province, Lumbini province, Karnali province, and Sudoorpashchim province. Kathmandu valley urban is included as a separate stratum. The survey includes 6 questionnaires: 1) a household questionnaire; 2) water quality testing questionnaire 3) individual women, aged 15-49 years; 4) individual men (ages 15-49) administered in every second household; 5) a questionnaire for children under 5; and 6) a questionnaire for children age 5-17 years, administered to mothers (or caretakers). Fieldwork teams observed handwashing stations in households, measured the weights and heights of children age under 5 years, and tested household water for E. coli and source water for both E. coli levels and arsenic. The questionnaires were customized and translated into Nepali, Bhojpuri and Maithili.
Suggested citation: Central Bureau of Statistics (Nepal), United Nations Children's Fund (UNICEF). Nepal Multiple Indicator Cluster Survey 2019. New York, United States of America: United Nations Children's Fund (UNICEF), 2020.

Series: Multiple Indicator Cluster Survey (MICS), MICS Program Surveys
Summary: Algeria Multiple Indicator Cluster Survey (MICS) 2018-2019 is part of MICS6, an international survey initiative to monitor the situation of children and women. Topics commonly covered in MICS include immunization, education, child and maternal health, family planning and knowledge of HIV/AIDS. Five questionnaires were used in the MICS Algeria survey: (1) a household questionnaire (2) a questionnaire for all women aged 15-49 (3) children under five living in households, administered to mother and/or caregiver (4) a new individual questionnaire relating to children aged 5-17 years and (5) a drinking water quality analysis.
Suggested citation: Ministry of Health and Population (Algeria), United Nations Children's Fund (UNICEF). Algeria Multiple Indicator Cluster Survey 2018-2019. New York, United States of America: United Nations Children's Fund (UNICEF), 2021.

Series: Multiple Indicator Cluster Survey (MICS), MICS Program Surveys
Summary: The Cuba Multiple Cluster Indicator Survey (MICS) 2019 is part of MICS6, an international survey initiative to monitor the situation of children and women. Topics commonly covered in MICS include immunization, education, child and maternal health, family planning and HIV/AIDS. For the 2019 Cuba MICS, 8849 women and 3700 men, ages 15-49 were successfully interviewed from 11,966 households. Additionally, 5254 questionnaires for children under five were completed. A literacy test was also included.
Suggested citation: Ministry of Public Health (Cuba), National Office of Statistics (Cuba), United Nations Children's Fund (UNICEF). Cuba Multiple Indicator Cluster Survey 2019. New York, United States of America: United Nations Children's Fund (UNICEF), 2021.

Series: Multiple Indicator Cluster Survey (MICS), MICS Program Surveys
Summary:
The Chad 2019 MICS was conducted as part of Round 6 of the survey series. Topics covered include child health and mortality, nutrition, sanitation, reproductive health, education, crime victimization, female circumcision and HIV/AIDS.
A total of 18,967 households were selected to participate in the survey. Five questionnaires were administered, along with tests of household water. Modules included household, children under age 5, children ages 5-17, women ages 15-49, and men ages 15-49.

Series: DHS Standard Demographic and Health Survey (DHS), DHS Program Surveys
Geography: India, Andaman and Nicobar Islands, Andhra Pradesh, Arunachal Pradesh, Assam, Bihar, Dadra and Nagar Haveli, Daman and Diu, Delhi, Goa, Gujarat, Himachal Pradesh, Jammu and Kashmir, Karnataka, Kerala, Lakshadweep, Madhya Pradesh, Maharashtra, Manipur, Meghalaya, Mizoram, Nagaland, Rajasthan, Sikkim, Telangana, Tripura, West Bengal
Summary: The India Demographic and Health Survey 2019-2020 is part of phase 7 of the Demographic and Health Survey (DHS) series. Topics commonly covered in DHS include health care access, living conditions, child immunization, education, employment, maternal care, and health literacy. Fieldwork for this survey was conducted in two phases, from June 2019-January 2020, and from January 2020-April 2021. This survey collected information from 636,699 households, 724,115 women, and 101,839 men.
Suggested citation: ICF International, International Institute for Population Sciences (India), Ministry of Health and Family Welfare (India), United States Agency for International Development (USAID). India Demographic and Health Survey 2019-2020. Fairfax, United States of America: ICF International, 2022.

GHDx Record Title: Mexico - Yucatán Under-5 Baseline Household Survey 2020
Data provider: Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation (IHME)
Series: Mexico - Yucatán Under-5 Child Health and Mortality Statistics Project
Summary: These data are the product of a collaboration between the Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation (IHME) and the Universidad Autónoma de Yucatán (UADY). The objective of the project was to improve maternal and child health and the quality of health information in the state of Yucatán, Mexico through assessing the knowledge of alarm signs, and access and utilization of health services, among caregivers of children under 5 years of age. This dataset includes the results of a household census and caregiver interviewer. The population under study includes caregivers of children under 5 in 8 municipalities in Yucatán. In total, data were collected from 2,996 households.
Suggested citation: Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation (IHME), Autonomous University of Yucatan (UADY). Mexico - Yucatán Under-5 Baseline Household Survey 2020. Seattle, United States of America: Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation (IHME), 2021.

Series: DHS Standard Demographic and Health Survey (DHS), DHS Program Surveys
Summary: The Mauritania Demographic and Health Survey 2019-2021 is part of phase seven of the Demographic and Health Survey (DHS) series. Data collection was conducted in two phases due to interruptions caused by the COVID-19 pandemic. In addition to common DHS topics, this survey also collected information about domestic violence and female circumcision, maternal mortality, and migration. 11,658 households were surveyed.
Suggested citation: National Office of Statistics (Mauritania). Mauritania Demographic and Health Survey 2019-2020. Fairfax, United States of America: ICF International, 2022.

Series: Multiple Indicator Cluster Survey (MICS), MICS Program Surveys
Summary: Six questionnaires were used in the survey: 1) a household questionnaire; 2) a water quality testing questionnaire administered in five households in each cluster of the sample; 3) women age 15-49 years; 4) men administered in every second--i.e. every other--household to all men age 15-49 years; 5) an under-5 questionnaire, administered to mothers (or caretakers) of all children under 5 living in the household; and 6) a questionnaire for children age 5-17 years, administered to the mother (or caretaker) of one randomly selected child age 5-17 years living in the household. 7,072 households were successfully interviewed for a household response rate of 94 percent. In the interviewed households, 5,887 women (age 15-49 years) were interviewed along with 2,214 eligible men and questionnaires completed for 2,801 children under age five. Questionnaires were also completed for 3,248 children ages 5-17.
Suggested citation: Bureau of Statistics (Guyana), Ministry of Health (Guyana), United Nations Children's Fund (UNICEF). Guyana Multiple Indicator Cluster Survey 2019-2020. New York, United States of America: United Nations Children's Fund (UNICEF), 2021.

GHDx Record Title: Pakistan Social and Living Standards Measurement Survey (District Level) 2019-2020
Series: Pakistan Social and Living Standard Measurement Survey (PSLM)
Summary:
The 2019-2020 Pakistan Social and Living Standards Measurement Survey (PSLM) District Level Survey provides data at the district level for each of the provinces of Pakistan. The survey covers topics such as health status, housing, education, sanitation and water supply. The survey data can be used for Estimation of Multidimensional Poverty Index (MPI) as well as for monitoring progress towards Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). Additionally, this 12th round of the PSLM includes modules on disability indicators.
The district level Pakistan Social and Living Standards Measurement Survey (PSLM) survey is conducted in alternate years as the combined national/provincial level Pakistan Social and Living Standards Measurement Survey and Household Integrated Economic Survey (PSLM Social & HIES).
Suggested citation: Pakistan Bureau of Statistics. Pakistan Social and Living Standards Measurement Survey (District Level) 2019-2020. Islamabad, Pakistan: Pakistan Bureau of Statistics, 2021.

Series: Multiple Indicator Cluster Survey (MICS), MICS Program Surveys
Summary: The sample for the Fiji MICS 2021 was designed to provide estimates for a large number of indicators on the situation of children and women at the national level, for urban and rural areas, and for divisions: Central, Eastern, Northern and Western. 5,467 households were interviewed.
Suggested citation: Fiji Bureau of Statistics, Pacific Community Statistics for Development Division, United Nations Children's Fund (UNICEF), United Nations Population Fund (UNFPA). Fiji Multiple Indicator Cluster Survey 2021. New York, United States of America: United Nations Children's Fund (UNICEF), 2022.

GHDx Record Title: Dominican Republic Multiple Indicator Cluster Survey 2019
Series: Multiple Indicator Cluster Survey (MICS), MICS Program Surveys, Dominican Republic National Multipurpose Household Survey
Summary: The Dominican Republic Multiple Cluster Indicator Survey (MICS) 2019, also called the Dominican Republic National Multipurpose Household Survey 2019, is part of MICS6, an international survey initiative to monitor the situation of children and women. The survey is also part of the Dominican Republic National Multipurpose Household Survey series. Topics commonly covered in MICS include immunization, education, child and maternal health, family planning and knowledge of HIV/AIDS. MICS also provides data for tracking progress toward Millennium Development Goals (MDGs). For the 2019 Dominican Republic MICS, 22,295 women ages 15-49 were successfully interviewed from 31,488 households. Additionally, 8,422 questionnaires for children under five were completed.
Suggested citation: National Statistics Office (Dominican Republic), United Nations Children's Fund (UNICEF). Dominican Republic Multiple Indicator Cluster Survey 2019. New York, United States of America: United Nations Children's Fund (UNICEF), 2021.

Series: Multiple Indicator Cluster Survey (MICS), MICS Program Surveys
Summary: The Tuvalu MICS6 survey was the first collected in this country, with fieldwork occurring from November 2019 to February 2020. The researchers interviewed 695 households, along with 817 women aged 15-49, 501 caretakers of children under 5, 435 caretakers of children aged 5-17, and 291 men. Water quality testing occurred in 170 households. Average household size was 6.0.
Suggested citation: Tuvalu Central Statistics Division, United Nations Children's Fund (UNICEF). Tuvalu Multiple Indicator Cluster Survey 2019-2020. New York, United States of America: United Nations Children's Fund (UNICEF), 2021.

Series: Multiple Indicator Cluster Survey (MICS), MICS Program Surveys
Summary:
The Argentina 2019-2020 MICS was conducted as part of Round 6 of the survey series. Topics covered include child health and mortality, nutrition, sanitation, reproductive health, education, child protection, and HIV/AIDS.
A total of 14,968 households responded to the survey. Four questionnaires were used, including: one for households, one for women between the ages of 15 and 49 years, one for children ages 5 to 17, and one for children under the age of 5 years, completed by mothers or caregivers. This survey was impacted by the COVID-19 pandemic and field work was halted before all households were reached.
Suggested citation: Ministry of Education (Argentina), Ministry of Health (Argentina), Ministry of Social Development (Argentina), National Institute of Statistics and Censuses (Argentina), National Secretariat for Children, Youth, and Family (SENAF), Ministry of Social Development (Argentina), National University of La Matanza (Argentina), National University of Tres de Febrero (Argentina), United Nations Children's Fund (UNICEF). Argentina Multiple Indicator Cluster Survey 2019-2020. New York, United States of America: United Nations Children's Fund (UNICEF), 2021.

Series: Multiple Indicator Cluster Survey (MICS), MICS Program Surveys
Summary: This survey is the first time MICS has operated in Honduras. The surveyors interviewed 20,669 households, including 19,279 women (ages 15-49), 19,279 men (ages 15-49), 8,466 responses by caretakers of children under 5 years old, and 11,966 interviews with caretakers of children aged 5-17 years. Additionally, 5,033 households participated in water quality testing. The objective of these efforts was to obtain updated information on trends, determinants and consequences of child mortality levels, maternal and child health, fertility and patterns of reproduction in Honduras.
Suggested citation: European Union (EU), Government of Canada, Government of Honduras, National Institute of Statistics (Honduras), Secretary of Health (Honduras), United Nations Children's Fund (UNICEF), United Nations Population Fund (UNFPA). Honduras Multiple Indicator Cluster Survey 2019. New York, United States of America: United Nations Children's Fund (UNICEF), 2021.

Series: Guatemala Vital Statistics
Suggested citation: National Statistics Institute (Guatemala). Guatemala Vital Statistics 2020. Guatemala City, Guatemala: National Statistics Institute (Guatemala), 2021.

Series: DHS Standard Demographic and Health Survey (DHS), DHS Program Surveys
Summary: The Madagascar Demographic and Health Survey (DHS) 2021 is part of phase 8 of the DHS series, a comprehensive, nationally representative household survey. Topics commonly covered by DHS include education, health, nutrition, family planning, and household characteristics.
Suggested citation: ICF Macro, National Institute of Statistics (Madagascar). Madagascar Demographic and Health Survey 2021. Fairfax, United States of America: ICF International, 2022.

Series: Multiple Indicator Cluster Survey (MICS), MICS Program Surveys
Summary: The MICS 2019-20 is a nationally representative sample survey encompassing a total of 26,882 households; involving women age 15-49 years, men age 15-49 years and children 0-5 years in 1,111 clusters. One third of the households in the sample were selected for male survey. The survey has been designed to provide estimates of key indicators for the rural and urban areas in Malawi, the three Regions, and the 28 districts. In addition to the administration of questionnaires, fieldwork teams tested the salt used for cooking in the households for iodine content, observed the place for handwashing, measured the weights and heights of children age under 5 and tested household and source water for E. coli levels. The objective of the survey is to provide information on indicators for monitoring the welfare of Women and Children. The survey was carried out from December 2019-August 2020.
Suggested citation: National Statistical Office of Malawi, United Nations Children's Fund (UNICEF). Malawi Multiple Indicator Cluster Survey 2019-2020. New York, United States of America: United Nations Children's Fund (UNICEF), 2022.

GHDx Record Title: Pakistan - Khyber Pakhtunkhwa Multiple Indicator Cluster Survey 2019
Series: Multiple Indicator Cluster Survey (MICS), MICS Program Surveys
Summary: The Bureau of Statistics (BoS) conducted this Multiple Indicator Cluster Survey (MICS) with a sample size of 23,740 households in 32 districts of KP (including seven newly merged districts) from 1,187 sampled clusters. This MICS collected data on more than 170 indicators (including 33 SDG indicators), covered in 51 modules. Data was collected on six questionnaires including, Household, Women, Men, Children under-five, Children 5-17 and water quality testing.
Suggested citation: Pakistan Bureau of Statistics, Planning and Development Department, Government of Khyber Pakhtunkhwa (Pakistan), United Nations Children's Fund (UNICEF). Pakistan - Khyber Pakhtunkhwa Multiple Indicator Cluster Survey 2019. New York, United States of America: United Nations Children's Fund (UNICEF), 2022.

Series: Multiple Indicator Cluster Survey (MICS), MICS Program Surveys
Summary:
The sample for the Viet Nam MICS6 / SDGCW Survey 2020-2021 was designed to provide estimates for a large number of indicators on the situation of children and women at the national level, for urban and rural areas, for the six regions (Red River Delta, Northern Midlands and Mountainous Area, North Central and Central Coastal Area, Central Highlands, South East, and Mekong River Delta), for two big cities (Ha Noi and Ho Chi Minh) and for the ethnic minorities. The sample respondents include 13,359 households, 10,770 women (aged 15-49), 5,923 men (aged 15-49) along with interviews with 4,329 caretakers for children under 5 and 6,894 caretakers of children aged 5-17. The survey also included household water quality testing.
0
Suggested citation: General Statistics Office (Vietnam), United Nations Children's Fund (UNICEF). Vietnam Multiple Indicator Cluster Survey 2020-2021. New York, United States of America: United Nations Children's Fund (UNICEF), 2022.

GHDx Record Title: Mexico Continuous National Health and Nutrition Survey 2021
Series: Mexico National Survey of Health and Nutrition (ENSANUT)
Summary: The Encuesta Nacional de Salud y Nutrición Continua [Continuous National Health and Nutrition Survey] (ENSANUT Contunia) collects information on health and nutrition, and the performance of health programs. The 2020 ENSANUT Continua marks the first survey of the 2020-2024 continuous annual data collection series. Like the 2020 ENSANUT Continua, the 2021 survey included a module focused on families' experiences of the pandemic; the effects on income, food security, diet quality, and access to health services. Blood tests were conducted for SARS-CoV-2 antibodies to allow for estimation of the percentage of the population that has been exposed to COVID-19.
Suggested citation: Government of Mexico, National Institute of Public Health (Mexico), Secretariat of Health (Mexico). Mexico Continuous National Health and Nutrition Survey 2021. Cuernavaca, Mexico: National Institute of Public Health (Mexico), 2022.

Summary: The Ministry of Health compiles and processes data on registered births.
Suggested citation: Secretariat of Health (Mexico). Mexico Vital Registration - Registered Births 2021. Mexico City, Mexico: National Institute of Statistics and Geography (INEGI) (Mexico), 2021.

Series: Multiple Indicator Cluster Survey (MICS), MICS Program Surveys
Summary:
The 2021-2022 Uzbekistan Multiple Indicator Cluster Survey was completed in two rounds. The first round in March - June 2021 was interrupted by several factors, including the COVID-19 pandemic, and subsequently a new representative sample was selected in September 2021 with data collection conducted between November 2021 - January 2022. The first round interviewed 10,879 households. In the second round, 4,180 households were interviewed from a sample of 4,507 selected from the same clusters as the first round. 
The survey consisted of four questionnaires: a household questionnaire to collect basic demographic information, a questionnaire for individual women aged 15-49, an under-5 questionnaire, and a questionnaire for children aged 5-17. Questionnaires in the two rounds were similar though some modules were not included in round 2.
Suggested citation: State Committee of the Republic of Uzbekistan on Statistics, United Nations Children's Fund (UNICEF). Uzbekistan Multiple Indicator Cluster Survey 2021-2022. New York, United States of America: United Nations Children's Fund (UNICEF), 2022.

Series: Guatemala Vital Statistics
Summary: Guatemala Vital Statistics 2021 includes microdata and tabulations for births, deaths, fetal deaths, divorces, and marriages. Data is released at the second-level administrative division (municipalities).
Suggested citation: National Statistics Institute (Guatemala). Guatemala Vital Statistics 2021. Guatemala City, Guatemala: National Statistics Institute (Guatemala).

GHDx Record Title: Pakistan - Balochistan Multiple Indicator Cluster Survey 2019 - 2020
Series: Multiple Indicator Cluster Survey (MICS), MICS Program Surveys
Summary:
The 2019-2020 MICS6 Pakistan - Balochistan survey was designed to provide information for policy initiatives to support children and women's well-being. Its objectives included providing high quality data for assessing the situtation of children, adolescents, women, and households, collect disaggregated data for identification of disparities, to generate data on national and global SDG indicators, and generate behavioral and attitudinal data not available from other data sources. 
Six questionnaires were used in the survey: a household questionnaire, a water quality testing questionnaire, separate questionnaires for individual women and individual men 15-49 years, an under-5 questionnaire, and a 5-17 questionnaire. Data was collected using Computer-Assisted Personal Interviewing (CAPI). The total sample size was 21,380 households in 1,092 sample clusters. 23 clusters were not visited due to inaccessibility because of COVID-19.
Suggested citation: Government of Balochistan (Pakistan), United Nations Children's Fund (UNICEF). Pakistan - Balochistan Multiple Indicator Cluster Survey 2019 - 2020. New York, United States of America: United Nations Children's Fund (UNICEF), 2022.

Series: DHS Program Surveys, DHS Standard Demographic and Health Survey (DHS)
Summary: The Cambodia Demographic and Health Survey 202-2022 is part of phase 8 of the Demographic and Health Survey (DHS) series. The survey collected information on fertility, contraceptive methods, breastfeeding, nutritional status of women and children, maternal and child health, adult and childhood mortality, women's empowerment, domestic violence, awareness and behavior regarding HIV and AIDS and other STIs, and other health issues such as smoking. It was intended to allow estimates of key indicators at national, urban and rural, and province levels and was comprised of household, woman's, man's, and biomarker questionnaires, as well as a self-administered fieldworker questionnaire. 20,806 households were interviewed and a subsample of 19,845 women age 15-49 and 9,079 men age 15-49 completed individual interviews.
Suggested citation: ICF International, Ministry of Health (Cambodia), National Institute of Statistics (Cambodia). Cambodia Demographic and Health Survey 2021-2022. Fairfax, United States of America: ICF International, 2023.

Series: DHS Program Surveys, DHS Standard Demographic and Health Survey (DHS)
Summary: The Philippines Demographic and Health Survey 2022 is part of phase 12th of the Demographic and Health Survey (DHS) series, a nationally representative household survey series. Topics commonly covered in DHS include child and maternal health, family planning, nutrition, health behavior and knowledge, health care access and use, and immunization. For the 2022 survey, 35,470 households were interviewed. 28,372 women of those households between the ages of 15 and 49 completed individual interviews.
Suggested citation: ICF International, Philippines Statistics Authority, United States Agency for International Development (USAID). Philippines Demographic and Health Survey 2022. Fairfax, United States of America: ICF International, 2023.

Series: Multiple Indicator Cluster Survey (MICS), MICS Program Surveys
Summary:
The 2022-2023 Afghanistan Multiple Indicatory Cluster Survey is part of the 6th round of the survey series. It provides estimates for urban and rural areas at the national level and for Afghanistan's 34 provinces. The survey was comprised of four questionnaires - a household survey, an individual survey for women 15-49 years, an under-5 questionnaire administered to caretakers of all children under 5 in the household, and a questionnaire for children 5-17 years administered to the caretaker of one randomly selected child from that age group living in the household. Questionnaires were based on the MICS6 standard questionnaires.
23,213 households, 44,341 women ages 15-49, 32,989 caretakers of children under 5, and 20,068 caretakers of children 5-17 were interviewed.
Suggested citation: National Statistic and Information Authority (NSIA) (Afghanistan), United Nations Children's Fund (UNICEF). Afghanistan Multiple Indicator Cluster Survey 2022-2023. New York, United States of America: United Nations Children's Fund (UNICEF), 2023.

GHDx Record Title: Burkina Faso Demographic and Health Survey 2021
Series: DHS Program Surveys, DHS Standard Demographic and Health Survey (DHS)
Summary: The 2021 Burkina Faso Demographic and Health Survey is part of phase 8 of the DHS series. The survey provides estimates of basic socio-demographic and health indicators including topics related to fertility, breastfeeding, child and maternal health and mortality, mosquito nets, domestic violence, and child labor, as well as estimates of prevalence of anemia and malaria in children under 5. 13,251 households were successfully surveyed, and from those households, interviews were completed for 17,659 women aged 15-49 and 7,720 men aged 15-59.
Suggested citation: ICF International, National Institute of Public Health (INSP) (Burkina Faso), National Institute of Statistics and Demography (Burkina Faso). Burkina Faso Demographic and Health Survey 2021.

Series: DHS Program Surveys, DHS Standard Demographic and Health Survey (DHS)
Summary: The Ghana Demographic and Health Survey (DHS) 2022-2023 is part of phase 8 of the DHS series, a comprehensive, nationally representative household survey series. 17,933 households were successfully interviewed. Of those interviewed households, 15,014 women ages 15-49 and 7,044 men ages 15-59 completed individual interviews.
Suggested citation: Ghana Statistical Service, ICF International. Ghana Demographic and Health Survey 2022-2023. 2024.

Series: DHS Program Surveys, DHS Standard Demographic and Health Survey (DHS)
Summary: The Nepal Demographic and Health Survey 2022 is part of phase 8 of the Demographic and Health Survey (DHS) series, a nationally representative household survey series. Topics commonly covered in DHS include child and maternal health, family planning, nutrition, health behaviors, health care access, health care use, and immunization. For the 2022 survey, 13,786 households were successfully interviewed. Of those households, 14,845 women ages 15-49 completed individual interviews. In the subsample of households selected for the men's survey, 4,913 men ages 15-49 were successfully interviewed. Biomarker data were collected in half of the households that were not selected for the men's survey. Anthropometric measures were taken of eligible women ages 15049 and children ages 0-59 months in these households. Blood pressure measurements and anthropometric measures were taken for adults ages 15 and above in half of the households selected for biomarkers.
Suggested citation: ICF International, Ministry of Health and Population (Nepal), New ERA. Nepal Demographic and Health Survey 2022. Fairfax, United States of America: ICF International, 2023.

Series: DHS Program Surveys, DHS Standard Demographic and Health Survey (DHS)
Summary: The Kenya Demographic and Health Survey 2022 is part of phase 8 of the Demographic and Health Survey (DHS) series. This survey is nationally and urban-rural representative, as well as representative at the county level for some indicators. The survey consists of four questionnaires - a household questionnaire, woman's questionnaire, man's questionnaire, and biomarker questionnaire. It collects information on topics including immunization, child and maternal health, family planning, nutrition, health behavior and knowledge, and health care access and use. 37,911 households were successfully interviewed. Of these households, 32,156 women ages 15-49 and 14,453 men ages 15-54 were successfully interviewed.
Suggested citation: ICF International, Kenya National Bureau of Statistics, Ministry of Health (Kenya). Kenya Demographic and Health Survey 2022. Fairfax, United States of America: ICF International, 2023.

Series: Multiple Indicator Cluster Survey (MICS), MICS Program Surveys
Summary: Thailand MICS 2022 is designed to provide estimates for indicators on the situation of children and women at the national level, for urban and rural areas, and for five regional domains: Bangkok, Central, North, Northeast and South. A total of 1,727 sample enumeration areas and 34,540 households were selected at the national level. 30,008 households were successfully interviewed. In the interviewed households, 21,089 women ages 15-49, 9,452 men ages 15-49, 10,638 children under age 5, and 10,450 children ages 5-14 successfully completed questionnaires. The survey consists of five questionnaires - a household questionnaire, an individual questionnaire for women ages 15-49, an individual questionnaire for men ages 15-49, a children's questionnaire, and a questionnaire for children under 5.
Suggested citation: National Statistical Office (Thailand), United Nations Children's Fund (UNICEF). Thailand Multiple Indicator Cluster Survey 2022.

GHDx Record Title: Guatemala Health and Nutrition Epidemiological Surveillance System 2016
Data provider: National Food and Nutrition Security Information System (SIINSAN) (Guatemala)
Series: Guatemala Health and Nutrition Epidemiological Surveillance System
Summary: The Guatemala Health and Nutrition Epidemiological Surveillance System surveyed children from 0-59 months of age and women of reproductive age (WRA) from 15-49 years. Data was collected via interview, anthropometric measurement, blood pressure measurement, the collection of biological samples (blood and urine) for analysis of biochemical indicators and the collection of food samples for quantitative determination of fortification levels with micronutrients.
Suggested citation: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), Institute of Nutrition of Central America and Panama, United Nations Children's Fund (UNICEF), United States Agency for International Development (USAID). Guatemala Health and Nutrition Epidemiological Surveillance System 2016. Guatemala City, Guatemala: Institute of Nutrition of Central America and Panama, 2021.

Summary: The Guatemala Health and Nutrition Epidemiological Surveillance System 2015 consisted of a cross-sectional survey in a sample made up of 891 children from 0 to 59 months of age and 1,727 pregnant and non-pregnant women between 15 and 49 years of age, residing in 2,304 households that make up a sample with national representativeness. Data was collected via interview, anthropometric measurement, blood pressure measurement, the collection of biological samples (blood and urine) for analysis of biochemical indicators and the collection of food samples for quantitative determination of fortification levels with micronutrients.
Suggested citation: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), Institute of Nutrition of Central America and Panama, United States Agency for International Development (USAID). Guatemala Health and Nutrition Epidemiological Surveillance System 2015. Guatemala City, Guatemala: Institute of Nutrition of Central America and Panama, 2021.

Data was collected via interview, anthropometric measurement, blood pressure measurement, the collection of biological samples (blood and urine) for analysis of biochemical indicators and the collection of food samples for quantitative determination of fortification levels with micronutrients.

Data provider: National Food and Nutrition Security Information System (SIINSAN) (Guatemala)
Series: Guatemala Health and Nutrition Epidemiological Surveillance System
Summary: The Guatemala Health and Nutrition Epidemiological Surveillance System surveyed 961 children from 0 to 59 months of age and 2,018 women from 15 to 49 years of age. Data was collected via interview, anthropometric measurement, blood pressure measurement, the collection of biological samples (blood and urine) for analysis of biochemical indicators and the collection of food samples for quantitative determination of fortification levels with micronutrients.
Suggested citation: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), Institute of Nutrition of Central America and Panama, United Nations Children's Fund (UNICEF), United States Agency for International Development (USAID). Guatemala Health and Nutrition Epidemiological Surveillance System 2018-2019. Guatemala City, Guatemala: Institute of Nutrition of Central America and Panama, 2021.

GHDx Record Title: Côte d'Ivoire Demographic and Health Survey 2021
Series: DHS Standard Demographic and Health Survey (DHS), DHS Program Surveys
Summary:
The 2021 Côte d'Ivoire Demographic and Health Survey (DHS) was part of round 8 of the DHS program and, unlike previous Côte d'Ivoire surveys, did not include modules from the Multiple Indicator Cluster Survey (MICS). A national sample of 14,766 households were selected and interviewed. 
A total of 14,877 women aged 15-49 were enumerated. In a household sub-sample, 7,591 men aged 15-59 were interviewed.
Suggested citation: ICF International, Ministry of Health and Public Hygiene (MSHP) (Côte d'Ivoire), National Institute of Statistics (Côte d'Ivoire). Côte d'Ivoire Demographic and Health Survey 2021. Fairfax, United States of America: ICF International, 2023.

Series: DHS Standard Demographic and Health Survey (DHS), DHS Program Surveys, DHS Malaria Indicator Survey (MIS)
Summary: The Tanzania Demographic and Health Survey (DHS) 2022, also known as the Tanzania Demographic and Health Survey and Malaria Indicator Survey (TDHS-MIS), is part of phase eight of the Demographic and Health Survey series. Topics commonly covered in DHS include: child and maternal health, family planning, nutrition, health behavior and knowledge, health care access and use, and immunization. For the 2022 Tanzania DHS, 15,254 women and 5,763 men ages 15-49 were successfully interviewed from 15,705 households. Anthropometry measurements, blood pressure, blood smear and finger/heel prick blood samples, and urine tests were conducted for the presence of malaria, anemia, and iodine deficiency in a sub-sample of respondents.
Suggested citation: Bureau of Statistics (Tanzania), ICF International, Ministry of Health (Tanzania), Ministry of Health (Zanzibar), Office of the Chief Government Statistician (OCGS) (Zanzibar), Tanzania Food and Nutrition Centre. Tanzania Demographic and Health Survey 2022. Fairfax, United States of America: ICF International, 2023.

Series: Multiple Indicator Cluster Survey (MICS), MICS Program Surveys
Summary: The Benin Multiple Indicator Cluster Survey 2021-2022 is part of the 6th round of MICS surveys. It provides estimates for indicators concerning women and children at the national level and subnational level by department for urban and rural areas. Topics commonly covered in MICS include immunization, education, child and maternal health, family planning and HIV/AIDS. 16,790 households were successfully interviewed, and water quality testing was conducted in 3,665 households. Of the interviewed households, 18,436 women, 7,916 men, and 13,133 children completed questionnaires.
Suggested citation: National Institute of Statistics and Demography (INStaD) (Benin), United Nations Children's Fund (UNICEF). Benin Multiple Indicator Cluster Survey 2021-2022. New York, United States of America: United Nations Children's Fund (UNICEF), 2023.

Series: Multiple Indicator Cluster Survey (MICS), MICS Program Surveys
Summary: The Yemen Multiple Indicator Cluster Survey 2022-2023 is part of the 6th round of MICS surveys. It provides estimates for indicators concerning women and children at the national level and subnational level by department for urban and rural areas. Topics commonly covered in MICS include immunization, education, child and maternal health, family planning and HIV/AIDS. 19,694 households were successfully interviewed. Of these households, 31,134 women, 19,561 children under age five, and 14,571 children ages five to 17 were interviewed.
Suggested citation: Central Statistical Organization (Yemen), United Nations Children's Fund (UNICEF). Yemen Multiple Indicator Cluster Survey 2022-2023.

Series: Multiple Indicator Cluster Survey (MICS), MICS Program Surveys
Summary:
The Comoros Multiple Indicator Cluster Survey 2022 is part of the 6th round of MICS surveys. It provides estimates for indicators concerning women and children at the national level and subnational level by department for urban and rural areas. Topics commonly covered in MICS include immunization, education, child and maternal health, family planning and HIV/AIDS.
6,158 households were successfully surveyed. Of these households, 6,945 women, 2,850 men, 4,464 children under 5, and 4,210 children aged 5 to 17 completed questionnaires.
Suggested citation: National Institute of Statistics and Economic and Demographic Studies (INSEED) (Comoros), United Nations Children's Fund (UNICEF). Comoros Multiple Indicator Cluster Survey 2022. New York, United States of America: United Nations Children's Fund (UNICEF), 2023.

Series: MICS Program Surveys, Multiple Indicator Cluster Survey (MICS)
Summary: The 2021-2022 Eswatini MICS is part of the 6th round of MICS surveys. It provides estimates for indicators concerning women and children at the national level and subnational level by province for urban and rural areas. Topics commonly covered in MICS include immunization, education, child and maternal health, family planning and HIV/AIDS. 4,675 households were successfully interviewed. Of those households, 4,294 women, 4,401 men, 2,251 children under 5, and 2,551 children ages 5-17 were interviewed.
Suggested citation: Central Statistical Office (Eswatini), United Nations Children's Fund (UNICEF). Eswatini Multiple Indicator Cluster Survey 2021-2022. 2023.

GHDx Record Title: Trinidad and Tobago Multiple Indicator Cluster Survey 2022
Series: Multiple Indicator Cluster Survey (MICS), MICS Program Surveys
Summary: The 2022 Trinidad and Tobago MICS is part of the 6th round of MICS surveys. It provides estimates for indicators concerning women and children at the national level and subnational level by province for urban and rural areas. Topics commonly covered in MICS include immunization, education, child and maternal health, family planning and HIV/AIDS. 7,499 households were successfully interviewed and 1,858 households were tested for drinking water. Of the interviewed households, 5,523 women, 1,656 children under age five, and 3,131 children ages five to 17 completed interviews.
Suggested citation: Central Statistical Office (Trinidad and Tobago), United Nations Children's Fund (UNICEF). Trinidad and Tobago Multiple Indicator Cluster Survey 2022. New York, United States of America: United Nations Children's Fund (UNICEF).

Series: Brazil Hospital Information System (SIH)
Suggested citation: Ministry of Health (Brazil). Brazil Hospital Information System 2021. Rio de Janeiro, Brazil: Ministry of Health (Brazil).
